title: Britain's best and worst hotel chains - with surprise score for Wetherspoons
text:

Britannia has been rated the worst hotel chain in the UK for the seventh year running in a customer poll.

Guests gave Britannia one-star ratings in nearly every category, including value for money, comfort, and food and drink. It got an overall score of 39%.

Cleanliness was a major issue, with patrons calling the hotels “filthy”, “dreadful” and “scruffy”.

easyHotel, at 58%, and ibis budget, at 60%, were also among the lowest ranked.

More than 8,000 guests rated over 40 hotel chains for Which? Travel.

Wetherspoon Hotels topped the rankings for the first time, sharing the top spot with Premier Inn, the reigning champion for the last four years.

(Image: Wetherspoons Hotels)

Which? Travel’s Rory Boland said: “There really is no excuse for the grubby bathtubs and filthy rooms that we have seen year after year with Britannia, so it is best to avoid them.”

Britannia, which has 61 hotels in the UK, declined to comment.

On average guests were 10 times (31%) more likely to rate Britannia poorly in this category than across almost all the other hotel chains (3%).

When a Which? investigator checked in to the Britannia Lodge at Gatwick, they were greeted with ‘damp smells’ emanating from a clogged ventilation fan and a ‘grubby’ bathtub.

Even worse, an ultraviolet light showed up stains that could not be seen with the naked eye, on both the bed sheets and the walls surrounding the toilet.

easyHotel, which is on average cheaper than Britannia, had a 58 per cent customer score and managed to avoid any one-star ratings, but was mediocre in most categories, earning two stars in areas including bathrooms, bed comfort and bedrooms.

When Which? visited one of the budget chain’s sites in London’s Old Street the researcher found it had ‘all the charm of a hospital ward’.

One customer who had stayed in the hotel advised: ‘Don’t stay there unless you’re very drunk and there’s no way of getting home.’

Ibis Budget was only slightly better rated, with a customer score of 60 per cent. While it scored three stars for customer service, value for money and cleanliness it was let down by the quality of its rooms and its food offering.

(Image: Accor Hotels)

At the other end of the scale, Wetherspoon Hotels made it to the top of the rankings for the first time - sharing first place with Premier Inn, the reigning champion for the last four years.

Guests raved to Which? about Wetherspoon for its ‘huge stylish rooms,’ which earned it a full five stars in the bedroom quality category - and a 79 per cent customer score overall.

Wetherspoon - with prices as low as £39 for a one-night stay and £5 extra for breakfast - was also the most likely of the chains to be rated excellent for value for money.

Rory Boland, Which? Travel Editor, added: “If you are looking for a cheap and cheerful stay in the centre of town you would be better off choosing the ever-reliable Premier Inn or a Wetherspoon Hotel, where even with paying extra for breakfast you can expect extraordinarily good value for money.”

Best hotels...

Premier Inn - customer score 79% (average price paid £70) Wetherspoon hotels - customer score 79% (average price paid £60) Hilton Garden Inn - customer score 78% (average price paid £100) Radisson Blu Edwardian - customer score 77% (average price paid £139) Hilton Hampton - customer score 74% (average price paid £100)
